issue.title: Please provide guidance on how to use DllImportResolver with dlopen on Linux (xref #11901)

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Documentation bug or enhancement, does not impact product or test code

labels.name: question
labels.description: Answer questions and provide assistance, not an issue with source code or documentation.

milestone.description:
Note: Issues from Future will not be moved here en masse until September 2023.

Preview, Release Candidates (RC), and General Availability (GA) releases for .NET 9

issue.body:
This ticket relates to the solution by @swaroop-sridhar in #11901 by a now deleted user (@ghost). Since the original ticket got closed there is no other way than to refer to it in a new one -- _this one_.

The creator rightly points out the issue with not passing `RTLD_GLOBAL` to [`dlopen`](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/dlopen.3.html). But the remark by @jkotas that -- and how -- the semantics differ between shared libs on Linux and DLLs on Windows is of course spot on.

Alas, the .NET runtime appears to attempt to mimic the Windows point of view too closely and I for one have been unable to get the suggested workaround to work. That limitation I would say is in all likelihood very specific to `NativeLibrary.SetDllImportResolver` together with `dlopen`.

**So I'd like to request that someone provide a working example of `DllImportResolver` in conjunction with `dlopen`. In particular I am looking for a `DllImportResolver` that gets set early on using static initialization e.g. using `[ModuleInitializer]` and then performs its job without recursion.**

Because here's the issue -- aside from the superfluous `;` -- with the given example: it won't work. There's no `Interop.Libdl`. There isn't even a `Libdl` when searching case-sensitively throughout the 6.0.0 runtime source code (used that because it should be fairly close to the 6.0 version we have packaged on Ubuntu 22.04). Of course the question was answered in regard to an older version of the .NET runtime. But in the worst case that means that a facility that was exposed in earlier runtime versions no longer exists, thus making it impossible to sidestep the infinite loop.

Well, the first thought then is to create something like this:

```
[DllImport("libdl.so.2", CharSet = CharSet.Ansi, CallingConvention = CallingConvention.Cdecl)]
public static extern IntPtr dlopen(string libname, int flags);
```

... whose first disadvantage is that the library name required may vary across Linux distros.

But the biggest disadvantage is that -- due to using _this_ `dlopen` in `DllImportResolver` now -- I end up with infinite recursion and a stack overflow.

I am currently experimenting on how to sidestep this issue without ending up with an infinite loop.

But since at least two MSFT employees suggested `DllImportResolver` to sidestep the issue in a ticket that was decidedly about `dlopen`, I wonder which part I am missing.

**Could someone please fill in the blanks? Thank you in advance!**

-----

More context: we encounter the issue from one `.so` that uses another `.so` which in turn uses the Intel MKL via the traditional three libraries that the MKL link line advisor suggests (i.e. not SDL: Single Dynamic Library).

In our case this means `second.so` depends on `libmkl_core.so`, `libmkl_intel_ilp64.so`, and `libmkl_sequential.so`. Nothing spectacular really. These end up in `DT_NEEDED` fields in the ELF file and are getting pulled in by the loader -- which we've also been able to verify.

Alas, MKL makes certain assumptions about its libraries. When loading the optimized kernel functions for a given machine (e.g. `libmkl_avx512.so` and `libmkl_vml_avx512.so`) it expects a number of symbols -- contributed by one of the three MKL shared libs above -- to be available in the global symbol table.

As you may have guessed, this is where `RTLD_GLOBAL` comes in. Since the call to `dlopen` from the .NET runtime only specifies `RTLD_LAZY` the symbols are not being made available in the global symbol table and consequently the `dlopen(..., RTLD_LAZY | RTLD_GLOBAL)` which `libmkl_core.so` performs in its internal `MKL_Load_Lib` fail, because the prerequisite symbols are not yet available.

The customary solution -- apparently even endorsed by Intel employees on their forums -- is to use `LD_PRELOAD`. Alas, that's a patently bad idea, because for starters these symbols pretty much always will take precedence _and_ it theoretically lets you combine incompatible parts of the MKL. The linker will be happy, but the combination of loaded libs may not even be supported. Setting `LD_BIND_NOW` is a better approach, but still not satisfactory, because it requires outside intervention.

issue.title: Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App missing from dotnet distribution

labels.name: untriaged
labels.description: New issue has not been triaged by the area owner

labels.name: needs-area-label
labels.description: An area label is needed to ensure this gets routed to the appropriate area owners

issue.body:
### Description

Hello, as per the title this framework namespace is missing from the dotnet distributions version 6 and 7, I have not tested 8 but porting applications from Windows to Linux is blocked by this issue.

### Reproduction Steps

1. Install dotnet 6 or 7 on Linux following the Microsoft documentation.
2. Attempt to build and/or run any dotnet application built with reference to Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App

### Expected behavior

dotnet framework includes the basic libraries required for the claimed "cross platform" support

### Actual behavior

Dot net applications which worked in previous frameworks no longer run

### Regression?

Yes. Dot net version 4 and 5 applications run on Linux under wine, these new framework versions have rendered applications that previously worked in wine, unusable.

### Known Workarounds

Build applications using framework versions 4-5

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

review.body:
Overall it LGTM, but we need to apply some minor cleanup before merging.

@AlexRadch thank you for your contribution!

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -326,6 +326,26 @@ public static float Dot(Vector2 value1, Vector2 value2)
                  + (value1.Y * value2.Y);
         }
 
+        /// <summary>
+        /// Returns the z-value of the cross product of two vectors.
+        /// Since the Vector2 is in the x-y plane, a 3D cross product only produces the z-value.
+        /// </summary>
+        /// <param name="value1">The first vector.</param>
+        /// <param name="value2">The second vector.</param>
+        /// <returns>The value of the z-coordinate from the cross product.</returns>
+        /// <remarks>
+        /// Return z-value = value1.X * value2.Y - value1.Y * value2.X
+        /// <see cref="Cross"/> is the same as taking the <see cref="Dot"/> with the second vector
+        /// that has been rotated 90-degrees.
+        /// </remarks>
+        [Intrinsic]

pull_request.title: [RISC-V] Fix Microsoft.VisualBasic.Tests.ConversionTests
pull_request.body:
In order to fix Microsoft.VisualBasic.Tests.ConversionTests we need to:

- replace NYI_RISCV64s with proper float/double registers initialization in genZeroInitFltRegs
- fix jump distance binding logic by performing INS_OPTS_J_cond jump transformation when jmpDist exceed the maximum short distance

After this change Microsoft.VisualBasic.Tests.ConversionTests starts passing without triggering any CoreCLR assertion.

Part of https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/84834
cc @wscho77 @HJLeee @clamp03 @JongHeonChoi @t-mustafin @gbalykov @ashaurtaev @sirntar @tomeksowi

issue.title: Report StackOverflowException on NativeAOT on Linux
issue.body:
Uses almost the same code as CoreCLR to allocate an alternate stack for handling SIGSEGV, and properly reports a StackOverflowException.

Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/82334

comment.body:
> I was thinking that in the current state, the actual test could be merged and just the two helper exes would stay separate

Locating the helper exes would likely become a lot more involved since they'd no longer be at `${currentDirectory}/../${testname}/${testname}.dll`. The test was hardcoding assumptions about the test build that would no longer apply in a merged runner - it doesn't look like a straightforward conversion either.

But I am not opposed to this change at all, it was just a question to understand the reason. I don't have enough understanding of how we currently merge tests, I was not aware that we can use a single property to keep the test separate.

issue.title: NativeLibrary.GetExport/TryGetExport on Linux don't offer the same semantics as dlsym()

labels.name: untriaged
labels.description: New issue has not been triaged by the area owner

issue.body:
### Description

`NativeLibrary.GetExport` throws a `System.ArgumentNullException` exception when passed in `IntPtr.Zero` to as `handle`.

This makes it impossible to get `RTLD_DEFAULT` behavior.

### Reproduction Steps

Compile and run this:

```
using System.Runtime.InteropServices;

NativeLibrary.GetExport(IntPtr.Zero, "SomeFunction");
```

### Expected behavior

Return function pointer or `IntPtr.Zero`.

### Actual behavior

Throws exception `System.ArgumentNullException`

```
$ dotnet run /home/username/getexport-issue/bin/Debug/net6.0/getexport.dll
Unhandled exception. System.ArgumentNullException: Value cannot be null. (Parameter 'handle')
   at System.Runtime.InteropServices.NativeLibrary.GetExport(IntPtr handle, String name)
   at Program.<Main>$(String[] args) in /home/username/getexport-issue/Program.cs:line 3
```

### Regression?

No idea

### Known Workarounds

Call a `DllImport`-ed `dlsym()` directly with `IntPtr.Zero` for the `handle`.

As was pointed out in a comment here, [another workaround exists](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/71881) by using:

```
var RTLD_DEFAULT = NativeLibrary.GetMainProgramHandle();
```

in place of `IntPtr.Zero`. Probably close enough.

### Configuration

```
$ dotnet --version
7.0.113
$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS
Release:        22.04
Codename:       jammy
$ uname -a
Linux ubuntu 6.2.0-35-generic #35~22.04.1-Ubuntu SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Fri Oct  6 10:23:26 UTC 2 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

I think it's not specific to this configuration, after looking at the runtime sources.

.NET is the one packaged and available on Ubuntu 22.04 _without_ the .NET package repos.

### Other information

[`dlsym()`](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/dlsym.3.html) knows of two pseudo-handles which can be passed in as the first argument ("a "handle" of a dynamic loaded shared object"). These pseudo-handles are:

```
/* If the first argument of `dlsym' or `dlvsym' is set to RTLD_NEXT
   the run-time address of the symbol called NAME in the next shared
   object is returned.  The "next" relation is defined by the order
   the shared objects were loaded.  */
# define RTLD_NEXT      ((void *) -1l)

/* If the first argument to `dlsym' or `dlvsym' is set to RTLD_DEFAULT
   the run-time address of the symbol called NAME in the global scope
   is returned.  */
# define RTLD_DEFAULT   ((void *) 0)
```

(excerpt from `dlfcn.h` from GLIBC 2.35)

While passing `(IntPtr)(-1)` works fine and yields `RTLD_NEXT` behavior, passing `IntPtr.Zero` is simply treated as an error condition.

This makes sense for Win32 `GetProcAddress` but doesn't make sense for `dlsym` on Linux where various scopes for symbol lookup exist.

comment.body:
> [#71881 (comment)](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/71881#issuecomment-1179570792)

Thanks for pointing that out! I agree, that this is a viable workaround.

The linked issue has a few remarks though -- and it's closed to commenting there is impossible. One such remark is:

> Given that `NativeLibrary` exists to abstract away platform differences, I don't think introducing a platform difference would be a good idea. [...] (on Windows it could enumerate loaded libraries and call `TryGetExport` on each.)

Agreed that it's there to gloss over those differences. Alas, seeing everything through Windows-tinted glasses in this case is the issue. Windows does in fact have the notion of "the module that created this process". What it does not have is the notion of a process-global symbol table. And that's where `RTLD_DEFAULT` and `RTLD_NEXT` come in. That said: the suggestion in parentheses makes little sense in the Windows context. That's no longer abstracting away platform differences, it's creating new semantics -- and arguably wouldn't be `Interop` anymore.

Another commenter states:

> [...] I'm not convinced it is common enough [...]

And I am not sure how that's backed by data, if at all. Certainly those are valid and common use cases in the Linux world. Certain libraries outright rely on the fact that symbols are made globally available before they get loaded (see MKL in #93911).

Looking at the implementation and names like `LoadLibraryCallbackStub` and then at issues like #11901 really doesn't say "abstract away platform differences", it says "use this particular semantic on the target platform because it most closely resembles Windows".

And don't get me wrong, I _do_ appreciate many aspects of the NT platform and find myself defending its advantages against more fervent Linux aficionados on a regular basis. But abstracting platform differences in favor of one platform and at the expense of every other platform isn't exactly the spirit of cross-platform development. That's the spirit of "I'll port this fork-based Unix server to Windows" and then complaining it doesn't scale (because of differences in the expense for process creation, because Windows uses proactor pattern whereas Linux traditionally used reactor pattern etc.) -- just in reverse.

PS: I'll leave closing this ticket to someone else, because I don't want to bereave anyone of the ability to comment.

issue.title: [API Proposal]: Interface dispatch cache to avoid method resolution at runtime

labels.name: api-suggestion
labels.description: Early API idea and discussion, it is NOT ready for implementation

labels.name: untriaged
labels.description: New issue has not been triaged by the area owner

comment.body:
> The unsafe-ness is just a reason not to add it

Not the only one. Convenience too. Individual pointer for each method requires a lot of boilerplate code. Actually, I can do the same right now with delegates or even IL weaving (e.g. InlineIL weaver). Does presence of IL weaving should prevent introduction of new low-level API? I hope not. People use IL weaving as a last resort, because they have no choice (and me too).

issue.title: [browser][MT] unify pthread pool size to 32

labels.name: arch-wasm
labels.description: WebAssembly architecture

labels.name: os-browser
labels.description: Browser variant of arch-wasm

milestone.description:
Note: Issues from Future will not be moved here en masse until September 2023.

Preview, Release Candidates (RC), and General Availability (GA) releases for .NET 9

issue.body:
- bump default thread pool size to 32 and unify to that default for all tests
 - see which existing active issues are caused by the same reason
 - keep ActiveIssue tracking it, because we know that it's too large default
     - https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/91538
